content:
Great puzzle! I like it!

The only thing that wasn't clear to me was that I should continue swapping all the way through for each pass.  My original thought was that a pass meant that as soon as I found one to swap stop and start again.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I have edited the bold statement to include "...starting from left..." also added explanation on how the algorithm works for P=2.

My Python Solution:

n = int(input())
d = [*map(int,input().split())]
p = int(input())

k=0
while k<p:
    for i in range(1,n):
        if d[i-1]>d[i]: d[i-1],d[i]=d[i],d[i-1]
    k+=1

print(*d)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Solved in Lua.

Really fun, perfect for CoC!

2 Improvements I'd recommend: 

1) If possible throwing a step-by-step explanation of the process of comparing adjacent elements and swapping them would help clarify for people who don't know what bubble sort is. 

2) The example should be better, without understanding bubble sort you might assume that all it does is shift the numbers to the left with wrap around. 

If you re-ordered and simplified the Input sequence it might be more clear. 

Example:
2 4 3 5 1

The output would be:
2 3 4 1 5

There is just 1 thing I see here that you might want to add to the description.
You are not technically saying that the algorithm has to start "on the left" and starting "on the right" (for whatever reason) produces different results.

You are enforcing a very narrow implementation (which is fine), but you're not explicitly telling the puzzlers.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Le principe est très constructif, l'énocé clair et que le tri est un tres bon exercice algorithmique

In python the enter is false.

But,
It's a very good idea.
I think people will not take the opportunity to learn bubble sorting in 15 minutes
In the puzzle section everyone will have access to it whenever they want to work on more "basic" algorithms, but just as fun.

But one does not prevent the other

Stub code doesn't seem right in Python. This is what I get:

n = int(input())
for i in range(n):
    i = int(input())
p = int(input())

Obviously it doesn't make sense to ask for the implementation of any specific sorting algorithm in a clash of code by just checking a sorted result.
To check the correct implementation I thought of this workaround: The solution can be checked at any intermediate step instead of just at the end.
I may apply this to other algorithms as well if people like it :)
Thanks for noticing that, it slipped by me that the loop variable conflicted with my own variable. It should be good now.

Yes you are right, the generated code stub was suboptimal for some languages. I improved it and I believe it is better now.
Can you please check again and let me know if it matches your expectations? Thanks :)

I will consider creating a classical puzzle for this, and maybe for some other algorithms as well. For this CoC, my goal is that the algorithm is easy enough to code and the description is good enough so it can be solved in well under 15 minutes.

It never occurred to me to start on the right :D
Good point though, because it does indeed lead to different results. I updated the description to make it more clear.

Great input. I changed the example to not look like some sort of shift.

I'll have to think about a good way to describe the algorithm step by step, because I don't want to make the description too long.
